questions.question: He looks very tired. He ___ been working all night.
questions.explanation: 'Must have' is used for logical conclusions based on evidence.

questions.question: She ___ be at home. Her car is not in the driveway.
questions.explanation: 'Can’t' is used when we are sure something is impossible.

questions.question: It ___ rain later, but I’m not sure.
questions.explanation: 'Might' is used when something is possible but uncertain.

questions.question: He ___ be the new teacher. He just introduced himself.
questions.explanation: 'Must' is used for something that is very likely true.

questions.question: They ___ have forgotten about the meeting. It's unusual for them.
questions.explanation: 'Can’t have' is used when we are sure something didn’t happen.

questions.question: I’m not sure where she is. She ___ be in the library.
This ___ be your book. It has your name on it.
questions.explanation: 'Must' for certainty based on strong evidence.

questions.question: He ___ have seen us. He walked straight past without saying anything.
questions.explanation: 'Can’t have' when you're sure something didn’t happen.

questions.question: You ___ have left your keys at home. Check your bag again.
This ___ be the right answer. It fits perfectly.
She ___ be over 50. She looks very young.
questions.explanation: 'Can’t' is used when something is clearly not true.

questions.question: He ___ be at work. His car is parked outside.
They ___ have heard the announcement. They look confused.
questions.explanation: 'Might not have' expresses uncertainty in the past.

questions.question: This noise ___ be the wind. The window is open.
She ___ be sleeping now. The lights are off.
questions.explanation: Strong logical guess based on evidence.
